The Trump Administration may not understand, or may not care, about the negative impact its travel ban is having on thousands of people from around the world. But I care. I met with about 50 international students at the University of New Mexico to hear their concerns and their fears about the travel ban. It was tough to hear. Some are from countries affected by the ban. Others are from Muslim-majority countries not named in the ban, but the students are understandably anxious. Still others are from Mexico, South America, Africa – you name it. They are all grateful to be living and earning a degree in the U.S. They are proud to be contributing to this community and its economy. Yet they don’t understand, and neither do I, how their future is now in jeopardy. I promised to help however I can with their individual circumstances. And true to their character, they had great ideas for me to introduce legislation and make the student visa process, as well as the broader immigration system, less burdensome and more effective. Whether the White House and the Department of Homeland Security wants to hear it, I intend to let them know the stories of these students here at UNM.

As we say farewell to March, I want to share some history about National Women’s History Month.  Congress first designated March for this purpose in honor of the pivotal and inspiring impact that so many women have had within the United States and across the world. We applaud women from various cultural, ethnic, and national backgrounds that have made significant contributions to their communities. Their vigorous fight for equality, their technological innovations that have transformed the world and the female world leaders who incite infinite hope provide powerful messages that will transcend generations. I am proud and humbled to follow in the footsteps of so many inspirational women, like Jeannette Rankin of Montana, who was the first U.S. Congresswoman, Maud Wood Park who was the first president of the League of Women Voters, and Mary McLeod Bethune who raised money to pay for poll taxes for over a hundred female voters in Florida. These are the women who we must acknowledge and thank abundantly; not only throughout the month of March, but on a daily basis. These powerful and courageous women have left a path for us which leads toward hope and the promise of a better tomorrow.

Joe Salazar served our country honorably as Staff Sargent in the 497th Bomb Group in the United States Army during World War II. He enlisted in the Army on January 14, 1942, and entered service at Fort Logan, Colorado. Joe served in the Western Pacific in the operations office in coordination with the air offensive against Japan and completed his service on September 20, 1945. Prior to his service, he was a manager of a grocery store in Santa Fe. He and his wife have four children, two still surviving.    Unfortunately, Joe was unable to locate items he lent to the NM National Guard Museum in the late 1960’s. Those items included a uniform, medals, and personal letters to his spouse during WWII. Unfortunately, those items were lost, and the family has been working with the director of the museum to check the archives for these items.   I am proud to have worked with the Office of Congressman Ben Ray Lujan to reach out to the Army for his DD214 and Discharge Paperwork and successfully obtain the copies of the medals.  Today we presented Joe with the following medals, and our offices will continue to work with Joe to locate his military uniform and ensure it is returned to him.  American Campaign Medal Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal World War II Victory Medal Honorable Service Badge with Rifle Bar Honorable Service Lapel Button WWII

Thank you to everyone who worked so hard to honor Juliana Gutiérrez y Chaves Hubbell as part of the Historic Women Marker Initiative. Today’s ribbon-cutting for the newest scenic marker is a fitting tribute to a strong 19th Century woman. Juliana, along with her husband, Santiago Hubbard, built and managed a large hacienda that supported a mercantile and post office, orchards, vineyards and pasturelands for livestock, which they raised and traded. The hacienda was on land that was part of the Pajarito Land Grant, owned by Juliana’s great-great-great Grandmother Josefa Baca. It has been preserved as the Historic Gutiérrez-Hubbell House in the South Valley. Another descendent of Josefa Baca, Natasha Lucero Rajaram, and Olivia Sanchez helped celebrate the unveiling of the historic marker.

Moreover, the Republican plan will further raise health care costs by eliminating the medical expense deduction. Let's work together on bi-partisan tax reform that will expand economic opportunity and benefit all Americans-not just the wealthy few.

Like many others who care deeply about the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) and Community Health Centers (CHC), I am appalled by the vote we took in the House today. Cutting essential public health programs and kicking nearly 700,000 Americans off of their health care plans to pay for an extension of CHIP and CHC funding is illogical, unnecessary, and reprehensible.   CHIP is a critical safety net and provides more than 15,000 New Mexico children with high quality, comprehensive health care coverage.  Rather than playing politics with their health care, Republicans should recommit to the bipartisan approach taken in years past and work toward a long-term solution that provides the stability that the families who rely on this program deserve.  Time is running out, and Congress’s failure to act is causing many states to quickly run out of funds, jeopardizing life-saving health care for low-income children across the country.

I voted against the Resilient Federal Forests Act because it does not provide the Forest Service with the funding it needs to fight wildfires.  The Forest Service is currently underfunded and forced to borrow from non-fire accounts to put out fires.  This hinders its ability to conduct the routine maintenance and thinning that New Mexico’s forests require. Unfortunately, instead of solving the fire borrowing issue, this bill makes it worse by adding needless bureaucracy to combatting emergency wildfires.  I supported an amendment to fix this problem using the fire fix language from the bipartisan Simpson-Schrader bill. But Republican leadership refused to allow a vote on the amendment.

Today, we come together to honor the service and sacrifice of our nation’s brave veterans and their families. Veterans in New Mexico and across the nation answered a call of duty to selflessly protect our country. As we remember and celebrate their service, I hope you will join me in thanking these brave men and women for their courage and commitment.  Veterans and their families have sacrificed for our freedom and security, however we see time and again, the daunting challenges they face once they return home. Many veterans struggle daily to find employment and financial security, obtain stable and sufficient housing, and manage both the physical and invisible wounds of war. These struggles also greatly impact families and caregivers working with their veteran loved ones as they transition to civilian life. We must continue to care for veterans when they return home and ensure they receive the support worthy of their service and the benefits they have earned.  As we have seen with their recent two out of five-star rating, the New Mexico VA Health Care System is still failing to provide the high-quality services and care for New Mexico’s 160,000 veterans.  I am working on legislation to reform poor-performing VA Hospitals, and remain committed to doing everything I can to ensure veterans and their families have the resources, benefits, and care they deserve.  On this Veterans’ Day, let us recommit to our obligation to veterans who have sacrificed so much for our country.  To all those who have served and continue to serve our nation, thank you.

New Mexico is home to some of the best solar and wind resources in the country, which create huge economic development opportunities as our state struggles to recover from the recession. There are several renewable energy and transmission projects under development in the state. However, the GOP tax plan jeopardizes everything by undermining the production tax credit which makes these zero-emission projects possible. I voted against the GOP tax package that would reduce investment and long-term economic growth in New Mexico as well as increase taxes on working families.  As we have seen in Kansas, trickle-down economics is a nightmare and will only lead to crisis and decline. This tax plan not only provides massive tax cuts to the rich on the backs of hard-working New Mexicans but undermines important job-creating investments in the New Mexico economy. Further, the $1.7 trillion package that will have to be paid for by our children and grandchildren will force automatic budget cuts that will decimate Medicare, workforce training services, investments that grow small businesses, and agriculture programs that New Mexico’s economy depends on. I introduced an amendment to the tax package that was based on my legislation to tax opioid producers and manufacturers and create a permanent source of funding for opioid treatment, prevention, and research. This can make skin cancer especially deadly and difficult to treat. National Healthy Skin Month reminds us of the importance of maintaining healthy skin. President Trump’s decision to dramatically reduce the protected lands surrounding Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monuments is a short-sighted corporate giveaway that undermines two of our nation’s greatest national treasures.  These lands play an irreplaceable role in our nation’s culture, environment, and economy; they are a haven for wildlife and home to archaeological artifacts and recreational opportunities. No child should ever be publicly humiliated at school because they cannot afford their lunch. Schools should never force students to do chores, stamp their arms, or throw away their lunch because of their inability to pay for a meal. Today, I led a bipartisan letter to the House Appropriations Committee in order to ensure the Department of Education addresses this issue and protects students from these heinous practices.

I met with the Director of the NM VA Health Care System and discussed a number of concerns brought to my attention by veterans and VA employees. Constituents have continued to voice concerns about VA service issues, such as issues contacting health care providers and incredibly long wait times. It is unacceptable that veterans continue to deal with these issues after they have been brought to the VA’s attention time and time again.  I am sending this follow up letter to Director Welch asking him for his improvement plan as well as to initiate an audit on the most significant issues at the ABQ VA Hospital.  NM veterans and their families deserve the best care and services in the nation.  Anything less is a failure.

The Department of Housing and Urban Development-VA Supportive Housing (HUD-VASH) program has provided housing to thousands of homeless veterans, including many that battle chronic illness, mental illness, or substance abuse problems. The HUD-VASH program has provided housing to many of my constituents over the years and has been a huge resource for them. Across the country, the HUD-VASH program has served about 138,000 veterans since 2008 and cut the number of veterans without housing on a given day by almost half.  The VA has an obligation to continue this essential program and provide housing to our nation’s homeless veterans.

We sent a letter to top officials at the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Justice demanding an investigation into claims of sexual assault, harassment, and abuse within immigrant detention facilities. If passed, the GOP tax bill will not only provide massive tax cuts for the rich on the backs of hard-working Americans, but it undermines important job-creating investments in New Mexico’s economy. The GOP tax bill will lower the corporate tax rate by 14% and add nearly $2 trillion to the deficit over the next decade. While America needs tax reform, we should not support tax reform that will make the rich richer at a cost to American families. We need bi-partisan tax reform that truly invests in the middle-class, simplifies the tax code, facilitates job creation and economic growth, and ensures the wealthiest Americans pay their fair share.

This bill is the most destructive and immoral piece of legislation I have voted against since serving in Congress. The bill’s $2 trillion price tag would trigger devastating automatic cuts that will be used by Republicans to justify ransacking Medicare, Medicaid, work training services, or agricultural programs that the New Mexico economy depends on. It further erodes the financial security of countless New Mexico middle-class families by increasing their taxes and health care premiums, in order to help massive corporations pad their profits and reward their wealthy investors. New Mexicans deserve a tax package that prioritizes middle-class families and small businesses; lifts families out of poverty; increases targeted investments in education and innovation; incentivizes businesses to grow wages and create jobs.

I, along with Senator Tom Udall, Senator Martin Heinrich, and Representative Ben Ray Lujan, sent a letter to the Bureau of Land Management - New Mexico expressing our concerns with oil and gas leasing around Chaco Canyon.  BLM has a responsibility to address the substantive issues raised by the communities to protect human health and safety, the environment, as well as the unique cultural resources in the area.  We have to conduct proper surveys in order to identify and ultimately protect currently unknown priceless artifacts that may be buried in the Greater Chaco Region for future generations of New Mexicans to enjoy.

With less than 48 hours before a government shutdown, 800,000 Dreamers are facing uncertain futures and over 13,000 have already lost status and are facing detainment and deportation. This morning I submitted the Dream Act as an amendment to the spending bill and made my case before the Rules Committee.  All I asked for was debate and a vote; to let the democratic process work.  My effort was rejected.  For Republican leadership to hold hostage the lives of 800,000 DACA recipients while having the power and solution to resolve this emergency is reckless. Dreamers can’t wait on this Congress and neither can we. We must act now and pass the Dream Act before Christmas.

I cannot vote to kick the can down the road on life-threatening issues that Congress has known about and left unaddressed for months. Nine million children are at risk of losing health care as states run out of CHIP funding; 122 Dreamers are losing protection and are at risk of deportation every day; veterans continue to lack timely, quality health care and services; our national laboratories and homeland security programs do not have the funding they need to accomplish their national security mission; and countless Americans in Puerto Rico are waiting for emergency support for their stretched Medicaid programs as they try to recover from Hurricane Maria.  It is irresponsible, cruel, and heartless for Congress to leave Washington to go back with their families, while so many Americans are left abandoned.  The American people deserve better than governing by chaos.
